data.title: Emmet split/join tag eats opening bracket of following tag
data.body:
#8207 - VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.3.0-insider (d0c2b891903d73e83dcdc7786398ebfa764fc4ee, 2016-06-28T05:01:27.563Z) - OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-24-generic, Ubuntu 16.04 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Paste `
  • Item 3
    • ` 2. Put cursor before `I` in `Item` 3. Trigger Emmet: Split/Join tag, notice the opening `<` from the closing `li` tag is missing ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/16433471/3b274e72-3d3f-11e6-8618-98addde5b7e7.png) This is likely happening because vscode is trying being clever when the edit is applied, so it omits adding another opening `<`.

data.title: Emmet toggle comment is not supported
data.body:
#8207
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.3.0-insider (d0c2b891903d73e83dcdc7786398ebfa764fc4ee, 2016-06-28T05:01:27.563Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-24-generic, Ubuntu 16.04

http://docs.emmet.io/actions/toggle-comment/ seems to have been missed in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/8155

If we want to claim full support we should implement it.

data.title: Missing screen redraw after resize
data.body:
Testing #8222.
1. Open the terminal
2. cd to a directory with some entries
3. `ls -lasi`
4. use the left border to horizontally resize the window
5. make the console so narrow that text is 'cut off' on the right (scrolls out of the window)
6. resize console back to its original size
   -> text that was cut off in step 5 remains cut off

data.title: Resizing renders console usable
data.body:
Testing #8222. 
1. Open the terminal
2. cd to a directory with around 100 entries or more (such as node_modules)
3. run a `ls -lasi`
4. scroll to the very top of the console output
5. grap the top of the console to resize the pane
   -> console output disappears; console becomes unusable and needs to be closed

data.title: Emmet commands should be applied in a single edit
data.body:
#8207
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.3.0-insider (d0c2b891903d73e83dcdc7786398ebfa764fc4ee, 2016-06-28T05:01:27.563Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-24-generic, Ubuntu 16.04
1. Type `a>b>c`
2. <kbd>tab</kbd> to expand abbreviation
3. <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>z</kbd> to undo, notice the text is removed
4. <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>z</kbd> to undo, `a>b>c` appears again

Ideally there should only be a single edit and therefore a single undo.

data.title: [html] In HTML/XML, go to bracket would be more useful if it went to matching tag

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
#8207
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.3.0-insider (d0c2b891903d73e83dcdc7786398ebfa764fc4ee, 2016-06-28T05:01:27.563Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-24-generic, Ubuntu 16.04

/cc @alexandrudima 

Currently in a HTML/XML file, go to bracket will literally jump to matching brackets. In HTML and XML, tags serve a similar purpose to brackets, you indent at them, they open and close, just like brackets. It would be intuitive imo if go to bracket went to the matching HTML tag instead of work on brackets (ie. the `Emmet: Go to Matching Pair` command).

data.title: [html] tag matching should work when the cursor is outside of the tag but next to one of the brackets

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
#8207
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.3.0-insider (d0c2b891903d73e83dcdc7786398ebfa764fc4ee, 2016-06-28T05:01:27.563Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-24-generic, Ubuntu 16.04

/cc @alexandrudima 

Consider the following code:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/16432201/cef29f5a-3d38-11e6-873a-b59c0b854876.png)

Notice how vscode highlights the brackets from the `<li>` when the cursor is at the end, I believe this is how general bracket matching works in vscode. For emmet the 'current' selected tag is actually the `<a>` as revealed when using the go to matching pair function:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/16432388/93fd78ba-3d39-11e6-9abf-70774ed68667.png)

The bracket matching in particular make this jump quite confusing. While I don't advocate designing around how Emmet works, this issue could be resolved by bringing the HTML/XML "matching pair" functionality in vscode to work when the cursor is _outside_ the tag. Currently you need to focus the `li`:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/16432428/cc9bf1c4-3d39-11e6-8780-cccca42d2f44.png)

This is what I want when the cursor is adjacent to a tag:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2193314/16432506/286a7ab6-3d3a-11e6-803e-e80318a88970.png)

Ideally this matching would be the same as emmet in that when the cursor is in the middle of two tags not separated by whitespace, the tag after the cursor is highlighted.

data.title: Symbol renames get very slow and sometimes fail/timeout
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.11.5 (El Capitan)

This is while editing Unity CSharp scripts.  I'm using the DotBunny Unity integration.

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Use the "Rename Symbol" command to rename a private member variable.
2. Repeat step #1 a few times (1-3).

After pressing <enter> on the rename prompt, there is a pause before the code changes.  The pause seems to get longer after each rename.  The first symbol is almost instantaneous.  The second can take several seconds.  Then 10-20 seconds.  Sometimes the code never updates.

If I quit and restart VSCode (or wait a few min), the first few renames are fast again, but then slow down.

ActivityMonitor shows very little CPU usage by VSCode while the rename is processing.

First noticed this with the June release (1.2.0, I think).

  • Item 1
  • Item 2
  • Item 3
  • Item 4
  • Item 5
``` Balance outward works fine until the whole second is selected, if triggered again the selection gets indented. Resulting in: ``` html
  • Item 1
  • Item 2
  • Item 3
  • Item 4
  • Item 5
``` This also happens when balance outward is run on an empty file.

data.title: Failed to launch external program tsc -w -p .. spawn tsc ENOENT
Debugger stalls trying to inspect XDocument variable
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.2.1 (1.2.1)
- OS Version: 10.11.5 (15F34)
- dotnet --version: 1.0.0-preview2-003121
  Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a file with this line of code, linking to a 4MB XML file:
   `System.Xml.Linq.XDocument newXMLDoc=XDocument.Load(@"/Users/ron/Documents/xmlFile.xml");`
2. Set a break point just after this line
3. In the debugger, inspect the variable "newXMLDoc"

Debugger stalls for dozens of seconds while trying to inspect the variable

data.title: fix for "screen cheese with long error messages"
data.body:
Since the parent element has been set to display: flex, it's children does not uses some of the css properties.
Those has been removed and subtsituted with the flex css property.

fixes #8357

data.title: Multi app projects are problematic
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6 Beta (15G7b)

Problems:

 I have a repo structured as the following

```
.
├── .vscode
│   └── tasks.json
├── client
│   ├── .eslintrc
│   ├── node_modules
│   ├── package.json
│   └── src
│       └── app.js
└── server
    ├── index.ts
    ├── node_modules
    ├── package.json
    ├── src
    │   └── app.ts
    ├── tsconfig.json
    └── tslint.json
```
- When `tslint` and `eslint` extensions are installed, vscode is unable to find the binaries or configs for these tools. It simply looks for them in workspaceRoot.
  - it's however, able to find `tsconfig.json` without a problem.
- I've defined tasks like `npm run build` `npm run lint` in my sub projects. They are just simple shortcuts to tslint or eslint and tsc or webpack. When I create `npm` tasks in `tasks.json`, vscode is unable to detect the package.json file.
  - I can fix this by using `options.cwd = '${cwd}/app/'` but then vscode is unable to match the errors to the correct files. vscode runs the commands from workspaceRoot, but npm's output is relative to the project.
  - I cannot use `problemMatcher.fileLocation` to fix this issue because `global matchers and tasks can't be mixed. Ignoring global matchers.`

Expected:
- when running tasks, vscode should look for configs and binaries relative to open file location, unless configured other vise.
- when linting, vscode should look for configs relative to open file location.

This setup works without a problem on Sublime Text and Atom.

Hope this helps, let me know if I can provide more information.

data.title: Support real Integration/UI Tests

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I was looking into the extension `vscode-api-tests`, this seems to be a very limited integration test suite for vscode.  It doesn't look like there is any harness or way to do more advanced integration tests, for example clicking items in the UI.

Is there plans for this or what are your thoughts on expanding the integration test framework?

data.title: Integrated terminal: Shell args not honored on Windows
data.body:
Testing #8222 
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.3.0-insider (d0c2b891903d73e83dcdc7786398ebfa764fc4ee, 2016-06-28T05:07:32.441Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.3.9600

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Using the following settings:
       "terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "E:\cygwin64\bin\bash.exe",
       "terminal.integrated.shellArgs.windows": ["-v"]
2. Bash should echo all lines read, open terminal and run: echo 123
3. "echo 123" isn't echoed (only "123" is)

data.title: Lines containing spaces should be handled the same no matter where in a file

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: Testing #8232. Create a simple file without any file extension. In the following picture all green areas are showing lines that only contain whitespace characters. I can come up with rules why indentation guides are shown the way they are but I think all non-empty lines (including those containing whitespace only) should be handled the same no matter where they are in a file. I.e. the context of the line should be ignored.
